audio_caption: The audio begins with gentle guitar music, creating a relaxed atmosphere. A female voice introduces the recording as a special episode of "Design Matters" from the School of Visual Arts Masters in Branding Studio, and names several individuals, including Malcolm Gladwell, who will be part of the discussion. The group will be talking about "the Illustrated Malcolm Gladwell" and welcomes the listener to the episode. The speaker asks "why an illustrated Malcolm Gladwell?". A male voice answers, explaining that he felt like these books deserved to be thought about from a design perspective with the same care that is given to the storytelling. He states that Malcolm should be able to put "this thing on the table and have that be" something, referring to "Plunk failure," and then corrects to "Plunk value".

The audio clip begins with two people, one possibly male and one possibly female, engaging in a conversation. The female speaker notes that “people don't put enough into plug-ins", and also asks "what was there's a tipping point to the tipping point". The male speaker is saying "it's the storyteller", and makes the statement that he's taking something that's somewhat complex. This is immediately followed by a different male who says "sometimes these things take on a life of their own" and that "an idea just getting a kind of independent cultural momentum." He further suggests that these phenomena are not easily recognized. As the speaking section closes, soft, mellow acoustic guitar music begins to play. It has a calm, reflective mood. Someone then asks "can we talk a little bit about how this happened?”

The audio clip features a conversation about someone deciding to work with Brian and Paul. One speaker, likely female, asks how the decision was made to work with them. In response, a male voice explains that he knew Brian and thought his style would suit the project, and that he thought Brian would "get Malcolm." Then another male voice chimes in saying he was told a little about the project, and that he "kind of falls into that category." The first voice then asks how Paul got involved, after which the first male voice explains that Paul is very committed to his art, "relentless in pushing through these ideas" and very passionate. The third male voice states that he got to see "all these drawings come in from Brian."

The audio clip begins with sounds of affirmation, including "ah, oh yeah", "yes", "wow", and "nice," expressing excitement. A female speaker then asks, in a conversational tone, if the other speakers have been like "what?", referencing the name "Brian," and asking "huh?" A male speaker responds affirmatively, indicating that there were a few instances. He elaborates, humorously explaining that he kept vetoing one person, possibly someone named Brian, then recounts a specific situation where he ended up accepting Brian's suggestion for the final page of an "Outliers" document. This segment transitions into gentle instrumental music, featuring an acoustic guitar playing a simple, soothing melody.

The clip starts with the sound of low and ambient music playing in the background, setting a contemplative mood. A woman speaks, stating, "So, three years and hundreds of meetings later, you're finally ready to get started." She has a conversational speaking tone. A man then speaks, saying "I told Malcolm, I said I don't want to illustrate your book." He explains that he wanted to do something "completely different" than his illustration work, and envisions the project going in a specific way. His tone is calm and thoughtful. The background music continues at a consistent level underneath both speakers.

The clip features a male speaker who seems to be discussing a sketchbook, mentioning notes and drawings. He explains that he kept one particular drawing related to content description and envisioned how the artwork would go. He speaks in a relatively clear and conversational tone. There are no other distinguishable sounds in the clip.

The audio clip features two speakers, one male and one female. The male speaker describes something that would "align directly on the content" and other times would "go so far to the left or right", discussing how it would take the reader on "a parallel trip with what was going on in the book". The male speaker then mentions "the title pages" and how they "had nailed down fairly quickly".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker contemplating the creation of something that feels drawn into, describing an explosion and a fuse. Following this, instrumental music starts, identified as abstract and featuring strings, accompanied by a male speaker stating that certain words "don't need to be embellished anymore." There's then a female speaker agreeing, followed by the initial male speaker discussing how to create a connection between visuals, drawings, and writing, making them more obvious. Concluding the clip, another female speaker mentions an original sketch before asking a question related to a final image, followed by a male speaker stating he can't.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing how illustrations can distract the reader from a story, emphasizing that they should enhance the experience. A female speaker asks how the male speaker thinks this enhancement occurs. The male speaker explains how illustrations that are too unabstract and too specific with word-based elements can cause the reader to consciously pause and disengage from the story.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the role of fear in storytelling, asserting that "storytelling is all about is all fueled by fear," specifically the fear of losing the audience. He talks about constantly trying to keep the audience engaged and how illustrations might help with this. His tone is thoughtful and conversational. He expresses the belief that the illustrations serve to engage rather than distract. The audio ends with him stating, "you know, it's game over," suggesting the conversation concludes.

A man is speaking in a thoughtful and reflective tone, describing his father's approach to knowledge and the world, noting his father's division of topics into those he knows more about and those he knows less about. He praises his father's humility in areas outside his expertise. He reflects on his own approach when working with talented people, expressing a concern about interfering too much and potentially disrupting things.

A man is speaking about books and design, stating that "we're sitting here talking about a book" and that it's "the least fashionable time" to be designing them, especially from a design perspective. His tone is conversational and slightly assertive.  The audio seems to be a part of a conversation or presentation.

The clip features a conversation between a male speaker and a female speaker. The male speaker states "that also means it's the best time" because of opportunities that have value now, maybe more than they had five years ago, emphasizing "a permanent object". He notes that many physical books are going away, but some "type of books that are selling more" now than five years ago. The female speaker asks "In what way?"

The audio clip begins with a female speaker, officially introducing a collection as the "Illustrated Malcolm Gladwell", but clarifying that it is the "magnificent creation of Malcolm Gladwell, Paul Sahre and Brian Ray". She identifies herself as Debbie Millman, thanking the audience for joining her. This speech is accompanied by the gentle, mellow melody of a stringed instrument, possibly a ukulele or similar instrument. Applause follows after her remarks, transitioning back into the quiet background music.
